com.zorben.dns.rrdef.rdata

Class Wks

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.zorben.dns.rrdef.rdata.RData
      • com.zorben.dns.rrdef.rdata.Wks

  • public class Wks
extends RData
    Parses and stores data pertaining to the well known services record.
    Format is described below: 
      +--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+
  |                    ADDRESS                    |
  +--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+
  |       PROTOCOL        |                       |
  +--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+                       |
  |                                               |
  /                    BIT MAP                    /
  /                                               /
  +--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+--+
    The WKS record is used to describe the well known services supported by a particular protocol on a particular internet address. The PROTOCOL field specifies an IP protocol number, and the bit map has one bit per port of the specified protocol. The first bit corresponds to port 0, the second to port 1, etc. If the bit map does not include a bit for a protocol of interest, that bit is assumed zero. The appropriate values and mnemonics for ports and protocols are specified in [RFC-1010].
    For example, if PROTOCOL=TCP (6), the 26th bit corresponds to TCP port 25 (SMTP). If this bit is set, a SMTP server should be listening on TCP port 25; if zero, SMTP service is not supported on the specified address.
    The purpose of WKS RRs is to provide availability information for servers for TCP and UDP. If a server supports both TCP and UDP, or has multiple Internet addresses, then multiple WKS RRs are used.
    WKS RRs cause no additional section processing.
    In master files, both ports and protocols are expressed using mnemonics or decimal numbers.
    Author:
    Mac Crompton
    See Also:
    RFC 1035 Section 3.4.2 - WKS RDATA Format

      • address

        private int address
        An 32 bit Internet address supporting the specified services.

      • protocol

        An 8 bit IP protocol number

      • bitmap

        A variable length bit map. The bit map must be a multiple of 8 bits long.

    • Constructor Detail

      • Wks

        public Wks(byte[] rawData,
           int start,
           int length)
        Constructs a Well Known Services RData object from raw byte data.
        Assumes that a properly encoded Well Known Services ResourceRecord data object is stored in the rawData variable, at the start index, of length length.
        Parameters:
        rawData - Raw byte data containing the Well Known Services ResourceRecord data.
        start - Byte index indicating the beginning of this data object.
        length - Length in bytes indicating the size of this data object.

      • getAddress

        public int getAddress()
        Returns:
        The IPv4 address supporting the specified well known services.

      • getProtocol

        public byte getProtocol()
        Returns:
        An 8-bit integer representing the protocol running the well known services.

      • getBitmap

        public byte[] getBitmap()
        Returns:
        The bitmap, in sets of 8 bits, indicating the ports for which well known services are being supported on.
